qas.question: Why is adding two characters at the ned of a line problemsome?

answers.text: introduces unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone

qas.question: What id Multics use to simplify plain text data?

answers.text: line feed (LF) alone as a line terminator

qas.question: Who adopted this practice from Multics?

answers.text: Unix and Unix-like systems, and Amiga systems

qas.question: What used carriage return(CR) alone as a line terminator?

answers.text: Macintosh OS, Apple DOS, and ProDOS

qas.question: When did Apple replace their CR with line feed (LF)?

answers.text: since Apple replaced these operating systems with the Unix-based OS X operating system

plausible_answers.text: introduces unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone

qas.question: Why is adding the Unix-based operating system at the end of a line problemsome?

plausible_answers.text: line feed (LF) alone as a line terminator

plausible_answers.text: Unix and Unix-like systems, and Amiga systems

qas.question: When did Amiga stystems replace their CR with line feed (LF)?

context: Unfortunately, requiring two characters to mark the end of a line <a0_0><b5_0>introduces unnecessary complexity and questions as to how to interpret each character when encountered alone<b5_0/><a0_0/>. To simplify matters plain text data streams, including files, on Multics used <a1_0><b6_0>line feed (LF) alone as a line terminator<b6_0/><a1_0/>. <a2_0><b7_0>Unix and Unix-like systems, and Amiga systems<b7_0/><a2_0/>, adopted this convention from Multics. The original <a3_0><b8_0>Macintosh OS, Apple DOS, and ProDOS<b8_0/><a3_0/>, on the other hand, used carriage return (CR) alone as a line terminator; however, <a4_0><b9_0>since Apple replaced these operating systems with the Unix-based OS X operating system<b9_0/><a4_0/>, they now use line feed (LF) as well.
